{{Italic title}} '''''The History of Cardenio''''', often referred to as merely '''''Cardenio''''', is a [[lost work|lost play]], known to have been performed by the [[King's Men (playing company)|King's Men]], a London theatre company, in 1613.<ref>Chambers, E. K. ''The Elizabethan Stage.'' 4 Volumes, Oxford, Clarendon Press, 1923. Vol 2, page 17.</ref> The play is attributed to [[William Shakespeare]] and [[John Fletcher (playwright)|John Fletcher]] in a [[Stationers' Register]] entry of 1653. The content of the play is not known, but it was likely to have been based on an episode in [[Miguel de Cervantes]]' ''[[Don Quixote]]'' involving the character [[List of Don Quixote characters|Cardenio]], a young man who has been driven mad and lives in the [[Sierra Morena]]. [[Thomas Shelton (translator)|Thomas Shelton]]'s translation of the First Part of ''Don Quixote'' was published in 1612, and would thus have been available to the presumed authors of the play.
Two existing plays have been put forward as being related to the lost play. A song, "Woods, Rocks and Mountains", set to music by [[Robert Johnson (English composer)|Robert Johnson]], has also been linked to it.<ref>[[Richard Wilson (scholar)|Richard Wilson]], ''Secret Shakespeare: studies in theatre, religion and resistance'', [[Manchester University Press]] 2004 ([https://books.google.com/books?id=rdSyQbU3SS4C&pg=PA233&lpg=PA233&dq=cardenio+wood&source=web&ots=QfRMoJ7jRN&sig=D1dFtqUAKIkZT-dv1bwHpMOaccw#PPA232,M1 p.233] on Google books). This source refers to Michael Wood's claims regarding Shakespeare's authorship of "Woods, rocks, and mountains".</ref><ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZFiWwHnyWUw "Woods Rocks and Mountains"] performed on Youtube</ref>
==Attribution== Although there are records of the play having been performed, there is no information about its authorship earlier than a 1653 entry in the Stationers' Register. The entry was made by [[Humphrey Moseley]], a bookseller and publisher, who was thereby asserting his right to publish the work. Moseley is not necessarily to be trusted on the question of authorship, as he is known to have falsely used Shakespeare's name in other such entries.<ref>{{cite book|last=Dominik|first=Mark|title=William Shakespeare and 'The Birth of Merlin'|edition=1991|year=1985|publisher=[[Philosophical Library]]|location=New York|isbn=0-945088-03-5|page=270}}</ref> It may be that he was using Shakespeare's name to increase interest in the play.<ref name="Maltby20110201">{{cite news|url=http://www.spectator.co.uk/arts-and-culture/night-and-day/6662493/theatre-fake-shakespeare.thtml|title=Fake Shakes(peare)|last=Maltby|first=Kate|date=1 February 2011|work=[[The Spectator]]|accessdate=28 May 2011|location=London}}</ref> However, some modern scholarship accepts Moseley's attribution, placing the lost work in the same category of collaboration between Fletcher and Shakespeare as ''[[The Two Noble Kinsmen]]''.<ref>A. Luis Pujante, "''Double Falsehood'' and the Verbal Parallels with Shelton's ''Don Quixote''," ''Shakespeare Survey'', Vol. 51 (1998), pp. 95–106.</ref> Fletcher based several of his later plays on works by Cervantes, so his involvement is plausible.
==Synopsis of "Cardenio", the episode in the novel ''Don Quixote''== After a few adventures together, Don Quixote and Sancho discover a bag full of gold coins along with some papers, which include a sonnet describing the poet's romantic troubles. Don Quixote and Sancho search for the person to whom the gold and the papers belong. They find him; it is Cardenio, a strange bare-footed character who leaps about from rock to rock like a mountain goat and whose clothes are in shreds. Cardenio, who lives in the hollow formed in a cork tree, rants and rages in anger regarding one Don Fernando.
Cardenio then relates to Don Quixote and Sancho the miserable story of his love for the wealthy and beautiful Luscinda: after Cardenio had received a letter from Luscinda suggesting that she might accept his proposal of marriage, he asks his wealthy and noble friend Don Fernando to arrange the wedding. Don Fernando has recently seduced and agreed to marry a young woman named Dorotea, but when he meets Luscinda he decides to steal her from Cardenio. To do this, he sends Cardenio away on an errand. Luscinda then writes a letter to Cardenio to alert him to the fact that he is being double-crossed, and that her father has agreed to have her marry the wealthy Don Fernando. She tells Cardenio that she is in her wedding gown, and that "the traitor Don Fernando", along with her father and witnesses, are all assembled for the wedding. She secretly has a knife hidden in the folds of her dress, and she intends to commit suicide. Cardenio arrives and hides behind a tapestry to watch the nuptials. When it comes time to exchange the vows, Luscinda pauses, and then in a dismayed voice says "I will". The bridegroom goes to kiss his bride, but she swoons. Cardenio, upset, hops on his donkey, leaves town, and becomes an angry man living in the mountains.
Luscinda runs away to flee her new husband. The story ends with all the principals being brought together, including Dorotea, who had also run away from Don Fernando, and with loose ends being tied up: Don Fernando repents and apologizes to a forgiving Cardenio. Cardenio is reunited with Luscinda, and Don Fernando is reunited with Dorotea.<ref>Cervantes. ''Don Quixote''. Wordsworth Editions (1997) {{ISBN|9781853267956}}</ref>
==Lewis Theobald and ''Double Falshood''== {{main|Double Falsehood}} In 1727, [[Lewis Theobald]] claimed to have obtained three [[Restoration (1660)|Restoration]]-era manuscripts of an unnamed play by Shakespeare, which he edited, "improved", and released under the name ''[[Double Falshood|Double Falshood, or the Distrest Lovers]]''. ''Double Falshood'' has the plot of the "Cardenio" episode in ''Don Quixote''.
It has been suggested that Theobald was unable to publish the original script, because of [[Jacob Tonson]]'s exclusive copyright on Shakespeare's plays. But that contention has been discounted, as the Tonson copyright applied only to the plays he had already published, not to any newly discovered play by Shakespeare; and Theobald edited an edition of the complete works for Tonson, whose commercial interests would have been substantially bettered if he had been able to advertise the edition as containing a hitherto "lost" play. (A prior instance of commercially "enhancing" an edition of Shakespeare's plays by adding new ones was the second reprint of the Third Folio of 1664, which added seven plays, only one of which (''[[Pericles, Prince of Tyre|Pericles]]'') has been accepted as at least partly by Shakespeare.)
The fate of Theobald's three alleged manuscripts is unknown. The very existence of three genuine manuscripts of that age is problematical, and Theobald was said to have invited interested persons to view the alleged manuscript, but he then avoided actually displaying them. These facts have led many scholars to conclude that Theobald's play was a hoax written by himself. However, more recent [[stylometry|stylometric analysis]] may lead to the conclusion that ''Double Falsehood'' was based on one or more manuscripts written in part by Fletcher and in part by another playwright. The open question is whether that second playwright was Shakespeare. The text does not appear to contain many passages that may be even tentatively attributed to Shakespeare, but it is possible that Theobald so heavily edited the text that Shakespeare's style was entirely submerged.
In the late period represented by Shakespeare's known collaborations with Fletcher in ''[[Henry VIII (play)|Henry VIII]]'' and ''[[The Two Noble Kinsmen]]'', his style had become so involved that it is difficult for a listener or even a reader to catch the meanings of many passages on a quick hearing or a first read, so Theobald might have found it necessary to alter the text in a way that made Shakespeare's voice unrecognisable. However historian [[Michael Wood (historian)|Michael Wood]] has found an "idiosyncratic" verse in the Theobald adaptation which he believes could only have been written by Shakespeare.<ref name="Wood2003">{{cite book|last=Wood|first=Michael|authorlink=Michael Wood (historian)|title=In Search of Shakespeare|year=2003|publisher=BBC Worldwide|location=London|isbn=0-563-53477-X|pages=201; 315; 330|quote=If Shakespeare does not lie behind that, it is hard to think who else might}}</ref> Wood also asserts that the lyrics of at least one song by Shakespeare's regular collaborator, composer [[Robert Johnson (English composer)|Robert Johnson]], are related to ''Double Falsehood'', indicating that Theobald had access to a genuine original text.<ref>[https://www.pbs.org/shakespeare/events/event241.html "1612: The Lost Play"], ''In Search of Shakespeare'' series, PBS.</ref><ref>Wood (2003: 330) The song in question, "Woods, Rocks and Mountains" has survived in a manuscript in Oxford.</ref> As "Double Falsehood" is substantially shorter than any other play of Shakespeare's and is completely lacking in a subplot, which all other Shakespearean plays have, it is likely that one of Theobald's revisions was to remove a subplot from his manuscript version.
In 2010, the [[Arden Shakespeare]] published ''Double Falsehood'' in its series of scholarly editions of Shakespeare's collected works. The editor, Professor Brean Hammond, made a case for the Shakespearean origins of Theobald's play.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/8569101.stm |title='Lost' Shakespeare play Double Falsehood published |accessdate=16 March 2010 |date=15 March 2010 |publisher=BBC News }}</ref> In 2011 the [[Royal Shakespeare Company]] presented an adaptation of ''Double Falsehood'' as "''Cardenio'', Shakespeare's 'lost play' re-imagined," directed by [[Gregory Doran]]. The critic Michael Billington believes that this version is more suggestive of Fletcher than Shakespeare.<ref>{{cite news|title=''Cardenio'' – review|url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2011/apr/28/cardenio-review| last=Billington | first=Michael | authorlink=Michael Billington (critic)| date=28 April 2011| work=The Guardian | page=12| accessdate=3 May 2011}}</ref> In 2012 Terri Bourus directed a production of [[Gary Taylor (scholar)|Gary Taylor]]'s "unadaptation" of ''Cardenio'', an attempt to reverse Theobald's alterations of the original. Taylor's text along with detailed evidence supporting the view that Theobald had used the original playscript was published in a collection of essays the following year.<ref>Terri Bourus and Gary Taylor, eds. 2013. "The Creation and Re-Creation of Cardenio: Transforming Shakespeare, Transforming Cervantes. Palgrave Macmillan. {{ISBN|9781137344212}}.</ref> This text subsequently received its UK premiere on 18 March 2017 at the Mary Wallace Theatre, Twickenham in a production by Richmond Shakespeare Society in association with Cutpurse.
==''Double Falsehood'', a synopsis== The stage play ''Double Falsehood'' varies its tone from that of the episode in the novel and gives the story a fast-moving comic treatment. This is noted in the preface that Theobald wrote in 1727. All of the characters are given new names for the play: Don Fernando becomes Henriquez, Cardenio becomes Julio, Luscinda becomes Leonora, Don Bernard is Leonora’s father, and Dorotea becomes Violante. The play borrows from the novel’s plot events leading to and including the wedding: Henriquez is in love with Leonora, who has planned to wed Julio. Julio is sent away on an errand, and Leonora is forced to the altar. She gets a letter to Julio alerting him, he arrives as the wedding is occurring. The bride has a dagger hidden on her in order to commit suicide. Julio jumps out from behind a tapestry to stop the wedding, but he is overpowered. Earlier on, Henriquez has raped Violante, which motivates him, at the end, to marry her in order to make up for his misdeed. A significant difference between the stage play and the novel, is that the play contains a series of dramatic encounters between the principals that do not occur in the novel.<ref>Shakespeare, William. ''Double Falsehood'': Third Series (Arden Shakespeare) (2010) {{ISBN|978-1903436776}}</ref>
==Charles Hamilton and ''The Second Maiden's Tragedy''== {{main|The Second Maiden's Tragedy}} In 1990, handwriting expert [[Charles Hamilton (handwriting expert)|Charles Hamilton]], after seeing a 1611 manuscript known as ''[[The Second Maiden's Tragedy]]'' (usually attributed to [[Thomas Middleton]]), identified it as a text of the missing ''Cardenio'' in which the characters' names had been changed. This attribution has not gained much support among other authorities.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.shaksper.net/archive/1994/96-december/2877-re-shakespeares-voices-the-second-maidens-tragedy|title=Unedited comment posted on 'Shaksper; The Global Electronic Shakespeare Conference' website|last=Lavagnino|first=John|date=6 December 1994|accessdate=4 December 2010|quote=The Second Maiden's Tragedy is presented as the work of Middleton alone in the edition of Middleton's works that sixty-three other scholars and I are currently finishing up for publication by Oxford University Press. That view has also been the general consensus for the last fifty years; we haven't found anything in Hamilton's work to make us change our mind.}} Dr Lavagnino co-edited ''The Collected Works of Thomas Middleton'' for the [[Oxford University Press]].</ref>
Several theatre companies have capitalised on Hamilton's attribution by performing ''The Second Maiden's Tragedy'' under the name of Shakespeare's ''Cardenio''. For instance, a production at [[Oxford]]'s [[Burton Taylor Theatre]] in March 2004, claimed to have been the first performance of the play in England since its putative recovery (although a successful amateur production had premiered at [[Essex University]]'s Lakeside Theatre on 15 October 1998).
A full production of the play, which noted the contested authorship, was mounted at the Next Theatre in [[Evanston, Illinois]] in 1998. Another production of the play, billed as ''William Shakespeare's Cardenio'', was staged by the Lone Star Ensemble in 2002 in Los Angeles, directed by [[James Kerwin]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jameskerwin.com/cardenio.html|title=James Kerwin: Cardenio|work=jameskerwin.com|accessdate=6 August 2015}}</ref>
In 2010 the Aporia Theatre began work on a new edit from translator and director Luis del Aguila and director Jonathan Busby. It was presented under Busby's direction at the [[Warehouse Theatre]], Croydon, in November 2010. Critic [[Michael Billington (critic)|Michael Billington]] believes the play is more suggestive of Middleton than Shakespeare.<ref>{{cite news|title=Macabre and luridly enjoyable – but no cosmic burst of the Bard|url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2010/nov/08/cardenio-review?INTCMP=SRCH| last=Billington | first=Michael | authorlink=Michael Billington (critic)| date=9 November 2010| work=[[The Guardian]] | page=38| accessdate=12 November 2010|quote=[Hamilton] claimed...that a piece known as The Second Maiden's Tragedy was really the elusive Cardenio; and it is a newly edited version of this – boldly attributed to Shakespeare, Fletcher and a third co-author, Middleton – that is currently being performed in Croydon....the play is more Middleton than Shakespeare.}}</ref>
==''The Second Maiden’s Tragedy'', a synopsis== The main plot of ''The Second Maiden’s Tragedy'' borrows from Cervantes' novel the events leading up to the wedding ceremony of Luscinda and Don Fernando. The authors of the play create a series of dramatic encounters between (to use the names in the novel) Luscinda and her father, and Luscinda and Don Fernando, Cardenio and Luscinda’s father and Cardenio and Don Fernando. The wedding does not occur; instead, there is a dramatic scene in which the lusting Don Fernando (The Tyrant) sends his soldiers to grab Luscinda (The Lady). When The Lady finds out that soldiers will soon arrive and drag her off to Don Fernando’s bed, she asks Cardenio to slay her with his sword. Cardenio draws his sword, aims it at the breast of the woman he loves, runs at her — and this time it is Cardenio who swoons. Luscinda picks up the sword and commits suicide. Her suicide, her dead body, and her ghost, all play a part, as the story hurtles toward a climax of murder and revenge.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=YHpZAAAAcAAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false" The Second Maiden’s Tragedy'']. Publisher: C. Baldwyn (1825)</ref><ref>Shakespeare, William. Fletcher, John. Hamilton, Charles. ''Cardenio''. Glenbridge Publishing (1994) {{ISBN|9780944435243}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2017}} {{Use Australian English|date=January 2017}} {{Infobox military unit |unit_name=Torres Strait Light Infantry Battalion |image= TSLI (AWM 119169).jpg |image_size= 200px |caption=Members of the Torres Strait Light Infantry Battalion on Thursday Island 1945 |dates= 1941–46 |country= {{flagicon|Australia}} [[Australia]] |allegiance= |branch= [[Australian Army]] |type= [[Light Infantry]] |role= |size= ~ 500 men<ref name=Ball34/> |command_structure=[[Torres Strait Force]] |current_commander= |garrison= |ceremonial_chief= |colonel_of_the_regiment= |nickname= |patron= |motto= |colors= |march= |mascot= |battles=[[Second World War]] |notable_commanders= |anniversaries= |decorations= |battle_honours= <!-- Insignia --> |identification_symbol=[[File:Torres Strait Light Infantry Unit Colour Patch 1943 to 1945.PNG|70px]] |identification_symbol_label=[[Unit Colour Patch]] }}
The '''Torres Strait Light Infantry Battalion''' was an [[infantry]] [[battalion]] of the [[Australian Army]] during the [[Second World War]]. Initially raised as a [[Company (military unit)|company]]-sized unit in 1941, it was expanded to a full battalion in 1942 and was unique in that almost all of its enlisted men were [[Torres Strait Islanders]], making the battalion the only [[Indigenous Australian]] battalion ever formed by the Australian Army. The battalion was used mainly in the garrison role, defending the islands of the [[Torres Strait]], although in 1943 a detachment was sent to patrol [[Dutch New Guinea]]. Following the end of the war, the battalion was disbanded in 1946.
==History== The Torres Strait Light Infantry Battalion was initially formed as an independent infantry company of just over 100 men<ref>Hall (1997), p. 37.</ref> in May 1941, after the Australian government became concerned about the possibility of conflict in the Pacific and sought to free up other units for service elsewhere.<ref name=battle>{{cite web|url=http://www.anzacday.org.au/history/ww2/bfa/island_defenders.html |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20150317204151/http://www.anzacday.org.au/history/ww2/bfa/island_defenders.html |archivedate=17 March 2015 |title=Island Defenders|last=Seekee|first=Vanessa|publisher=Anzacday.org.au|accessdate=18 February 2010}}</ref> Recruitment for the company was impacted by the pearling season, but by December 1941 the company was adequately manned and assumed a mobile reserve role; as enlistments continued to grow throughout early 1942 a labour company was also established, eventually adopting the title of the Torres Strait Employment Company.<ref name=McKenzie2264>McKenzie-Smith (2018), p. 2264.</ref>
In June 1942, following [[Japan]]'s entry into the war the previous December, the decision was made to expand the unit and an appeal for further volunteers was sent out. The response from the Islanders was considerable, with 830<ref name=AWM>{{cite journal|url=https://www.awm.gov.au/about/our-work/publications/wartime/12/ilan-man|title="One ilan man": the Torres Strait Light Infantry|last=Seekee|first=Vanessa|work=Wartime|volume=12|publisher=Australian War Memorial|accessdate=18 February 2010}}</ref><ref>Hall (1997), p. 39.</ref> Torres Strait Islander men joining the ranks throughout the course of the war—almost every man eligible—a total equal to about one fifth of the population of the [[Torres Strait]] at the time.<ref name=abc>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/am/stories/s401912.htm|title=Torres Strait Star: AM Archive – Saturday, 27 October 2001|publisher=ABC Radio – AM|accessdate=18 February 2010}}</ref> In addition, a further 40 Torres Strait Malays and Aboriginals were also recruited.<ref name=battle/> By July, the garrison in the Torres Strait was augmented with the arrival of the 14th Garrison Battalion, and the Torres Strait Infantry Company was allocated a reserve role in support of 'B' Company, 14th Garrison Battalion in defence of the [[Horn Island, Queensland|Horn Island]] airfield.<ref name=McKenzie2264/>
The Torres Strait Infantry Company was further expanded by absorbing the employment company,<ref name=McKenzie2264/> and on 1 March 1943, the unit was officially established as a full [[battalion]]<ref name=Dennis4>Dennis et al (2008), p. 4.</ref> under the command of Major John Uther (Jock) Swain, with an authorised strength of 17 officers and 470 men.<ref name=Ball34>Ball (1996), p. 34.</ref> After receiving full infantry training to the same standard as units of the [[Second Australian Imperial Force|2nd AIF]], the battalion carried out exercises with the [[26th Battalion (Australia)|26th Battalion]] and the [[5th Machine Gun Battalion (Australia)|5th Machine Gun Battalion]] on [[Prince of Wales Island (Queensland)|Prince of Wales Island]].<ref name=AWM/> It was organised into four rifle companies, designated 'A' to 'D', and spread out across the Torres Strait, including Horn Island, Goode Island, and [[Thursday Island]], where it formed part of [[Torres Strait Force]]<ref>Ball (1996), p. 281.</ref> and served as an integral part of the Islands' defences against Japanese air raids.<ref name=AWM/> Later, in May 1943, due to the overwhelming number of recruits, a [[Assault pioneer|pioneer]] company consisting of 160 men was also formed.<ref name=Ball34/><ref name=battle/> This meant that the battalion could be released from labouring and constructing tasks to focus on defence.<ref name=McKenzie2264/>
Between October to December 1943, a detachment from the battalion was sent to [[Dutch New Guinea]], where they carried out patrol operations in search of Japanese occupation. On 23 December, they were involved in a skirmish with a group of Japanese, during which one member of the battalion was killed and six wounded.<ref name=AWM/> In mid-1944, the various elements of the battalion were brought together on Thursday Island as it was determined the outposts were no longer needed. At this time the battalion was reorganised, and formed a transportation company, which also took over responsibility for terminal operations and water transport.<ref name=McKenzie2264/>
Due to the racial policies in place at the time, all officers and senior non-commissioned officers were white Australians, while the Torres Strait Islanders originally only received one third of the pay of white soldiers of equal rank.<ref name=AWM/><ref name=Dennis4/> In response to this and other concerns, 'A', 'B' and 'C' Companies of the battalion briefly went on strike in late December 1943.<ref name=battle/> In February 1944 the Army agreed to increase the soldiers' pay to two-thirds of that of white soldiers. The indigenous soldiers finally received full back pay for their war service in 1986.<ref name=AWM/><ref name=Dennis4/> Despite the discriminatory pay scales the Islanders generally appreciated the Army's culture, as its discipline and hierarchy allowed them to be treated with respect by white soldiers.<ref name=AWM/>
The unit was unique, being the only Indigenous Australian battalion ever formed by the Australian Army, and although a number of small [[Irregular military|irregular units]] of Aborigines were formed to provide surveillance of isolated parts of the northern Australian coast, the majority of Indigenous Australians that enlisted during the war served in integrated units, with the exigencies of wartime emergency resulting in significant changes both to official policy and social attitudes on the service of Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders in the military.<ref>Dennis et al (2008), p. 3.</ref> The Torres Strait Island Light Infantry Battalion represented a significant contribution to the Australian war effort in terms of population, with the majority of able bodied Torres Strait Islander males of military age serving during the war.<ref name=Dennis4/> The battalion was disbanded in 1946, following the end of hostilities. A total 36 members of the battalion died on active service.<ref name=battle/>
'C' Company of the [[Far North Queensland Regiment|51st Battalion, Far North Queensland Regiment (51 FNQR)]] was established in the [[Torres Strait]] in 1987 as a [[Regional Force Surveillance Unit]] (RFSU) responsible for sovereignty patrols in the Torres Strait and providing security to the remote parts of Northern Australia.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://51fnqra.com/unithistory/postwar.html|title=Official Website for the 51st Battalion, Far North Queensland Regiment Association|publisher=51st Battalion, Far North Queensland Regiment Association|accessdate=19 February 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707064848/http://51fnqra.com/unithistory/postwar.html|archivedate=7 July 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Today, a number descendents of men who served in the Torres Strait Light Infantry serve within 51 FNQR.<ref name=battle/>
==Commanding officers== The following officers commanded the battalion during the war: * Major John Uther Swain (1942–1944);<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ww2roll.gov.au/Veteran.aspx?serviceId=A&veteranId=43329|work=World War 2 Nominal Roll |title= Swain, John Uther|publisher=Commonwealth of Australia|accessdate=20 February 2010}}</ref> * Major Charles Frederick Mayne Godtschalk (1944–1946).<ref name=battle/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ww2roll.gov.au/Veteran.aspx?serviceId=A&veteranId=186149|work=World War 2 Nominal Roll |title=Godtschalk, Charles Frederick Mayne|publisher=Commonwealth of Australia|accessdate=18 February 2010}}</ref>

Standard|FIPS code]] | blank_info = 25-71620 | blank1_name = [[Geographic Names Information System|GNIS]] feature ID | blank1_info = 0618387 }} '''Uxbridge''' is a town in [[Worcester County, Massachusetts]] first settled in 1662 and incorporated in 1727. It was originally part of the town of [[Mendon, MA|Mendon]], and named for the [[Marquess of Anglesey|Earl of Uxbridge]]. The town (population 14,137, 2017 estimate)<ref>http://massachusetts.hometownlocator.com/counties/subdivisions/data,n,town%20of%20uxbridge,id,2502771620,cfips,027.cfm</ref> is located {{convert|36|mi|abbr=on}} southwest of [[Boston]]<ref>[http://www.roadsidethoughts.com/ma/north-uxbridge-xx-worcester-nearby.htm North Uxbridge (Worcester County, Massachusetts [MA]): Around the Neighborhood<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> and {{convert|15|mi|abbr=on}} south-southeast of [[Worcester, MA|Worcester]], at the midpoint of the [[Blackstone River Valley National Heritage Corridor|Blackstone Valley National Historic Park]]. Two Uxbridge Quakers served as national leaders in the [[American anti-slavery movement]]. Uxbridge "weaves a tapestry of early [[America]]".<ref name="NPS">{{cite web |title=Uxbridge Walking Tour, NPS brochure |url=http://www.nps.gov/blac/planyourvisit/upload/Uxbridge.pdf |publisher=NPS.gov |accessdate=January 1, 2011}}</ref>
Indigenous [[Nipmuc]] people near "Wacentug" (river bend), deeded land to 17th-century settlers. Uxbridge granted rights to America's first woman voter, [[Lydia Chapin Taft]]. The first hospital for mental illness in America was established here.<ref name="worcester">{{cite book |last=Lincoln |first=William |title="History of Worcester, Mass. from its Earliest settlement to 1836" by Charles Hersey |publisher=Hersey/Henry Howland Press |year=1862 |place=Worcester, Mass. |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8MRCObZ79wEC&pg=PA222&lpg=PA222&dq=dr+samuel+willard+of+uxbridge+born+died&source=web&ots=S6ESRPlmUJ&sig=R_ZoRrfb3opH2W7xVR64NWE6Inc}}</ref><ref name="cwmars1">{{cite web |url=http://dlib.cwmars.org/cdm4/item_viewer.php?CISOROOT=%2Fuxbridge&CISOPTR=48 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-01-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203071601/http://dlib.cwmars.org/cdm4/item_viewer.php?CISOROOT=%2Fuxbridge&CISOPTR=48 |archivedate=December 3, 2013 |df=mdy-all }} Digital Treasures, Samuel Willard ran a "hospital for the insane", and trained young physicians, east side of Uxbridge Common (no longer standing)</ref> [[Deborah Sampson]] posed as an Uxbridge soldier, and fought in the [[American Revolution]]. A 140-year legacy of manufacturing military uniforms and clothing began with 1820 [[power looms]]. The Board of Selectmen approved Massachusetts's first women jurors. Uxbridge became famous for woolen [[cashmere wool|cashmeres]]. "Uxbridge Blue", was the first [[US Air Force]] Dress Uniform.<ref>[http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,819703,00.html Business: Time Clock, ''Time'' Magazine, March 29, 1954]</ref> [[BJ's Wholesale Club]] distribution warehouse is a major employer today.
== History == {{Main|History of Uxbridge, Massachusetts}}
=== Colonial era, Revolution, Quakers, and abolition === [[John Eliot (missionary)|John Eliot]] started [[Nipmuc]] [[Praying Indian]] villages.<ref name="MHC"/><ref name="nipmuc">{{cite web |title=Nipmuc History |publisher=Lee Sultzman |url=http://www.dickshovel.com/nipmuc.html |accessdate=September 28, 2007}}</ref><ref name="names">{{cite web |title=Nipmuc place names of New England|publisher=native tech.org |url=http://www.nativetech.org/Nipmuc/placenames/mainmass.html |accessdate=April 12, 2008}}</ref> "Wacentug" natives sold land to settlers in 1662,<ref name="hist">{{cite book |last=Marvin |first=Rev. Abijah Perkins |title=History of Worcester County, Massachusetts, Embracing a Comprehensive History of the County from its earliest beginnings to the present time; Vol. II |publisher=CF Jewitt and Company |year=1879 |location=Boston, MA |pages=421–436 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Rj4WqxsQu5UC&pg=PA429&lpg=PA429&dq=rev+nathan+webb+year+of+death}}</ref> "for 24 pound Ster".<ref name="hist" /><ref name="hist" /><ref name="mendon">{{cite book |last=Connole |first=Dennis A. |authorlink=|title=The Indians of the Nipmuck Country in Southern New England, 1630–1750: A Historical Geography |publisher=McFarland and Company (Accessed by Google Books) |year=2001 |location=|page=146 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kTYkoJlemB4C&pg=PA7&lpg=PA7&dq=connole+dennis+a+2001+the+indians+of+the+nipmuck+country+in+southern+new+england+%221630+1750%22 |isbn=978-0-7864-0799-6}}</ref> [[Mendon, MA|Mendon]] began in 1667, and burned in [[King Phillips War]]. Western Mendon became Uxbridge in 1727, and [[Coronet John Farnum Jr. House|Farnum House]] held the first [[town meeting]].<ref name="farnum">{{cite web |title=John Farnum |publisher=Doug Sinclair's Archives |url=http://dougsinclairsarchives.com/farnum/johnfarnum2.htm |accessdate=October 4, 2007}}</ref> [[Nathan Webb]]'s church was the colony's first new Congregational church in the [[First Great Awakening|Great Awakening]].<ref name="church">{{cite book |last=Clarke, D.D. |first=Joseph S. |authorlink=|title=A Historical Sketch of the Congregational Churches in Massachusetts, from 1620 to 1858 |publisher=Congregational Board of Publication |year=1858 |location=Boston (Digitized by Google books) |page=148 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=L7yETClx8EUC&pg=PA148&lpg=PA148&dq=great+awakening+uxbridge+mass |doi=|id=|isbn=}}</ref> [[Lydia Chapin Taft]] voted in the 1756 town meeting, a first for [[women's suffrage|women]].<ref name="Washington" />
[[Seth Read|Seth]] and [[Joseph Read]] and [[Simeon Wheelock]] joined [[Committee of correspondence|Committees of Correspondence]].<ref name="Seth">{{cite book |last=Buford |first=Mary Hunter |authorlink=|title=Seth Read, Lieut.-Col.Continental Army; Pioneer at Geneva, New York, 1787, and at Erie, Penn., June, 1795. His Ancestors and Descendants. |year=1895 |location=Boston, Mass. |pages=167 pages on CD in PDF Format. |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ABlMAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA5&lpg=PA5&dq=buford+mary+hunter+1895+%22seth+read%22}}</ref> [[Baxter Hall]] was a Minuteman drummer.<ref name="music">{{cite web |title=Martial Musick in Uxbridge Massachusetts 1727–present |publisher=www.angelfire.com |url=http://www.angelfire.com/music2/uxbmarmusic/ |accessdate=September 23, 2007}}</ref> Seth Read fought at [[Battle of Bunker Hill|Bunker Hill]]. Washington stopped at Reed's tavern, en route to command the [[Continental Army]].<ref name="vitals">{{cite book |last=Baldwin |first=Thomas Williams |authorlink=|title=Vital Records of Uxbridge, Massachusetts to the Year 1850 |publisher=Wright and Potter Printing|location=Boston |pages=2–450 |year=1916 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6lj7wmu0U2IC&dq=Samuel+Taft+of+Uxbridge&pg=PA235&cd=2 |accessdate=November 2, 2007}}</ref><ref name="collections">{{cite book|title=Collections of the Worcester Society of Antiquity |series=Volume XIV |publisher=googlebooks |page=34 |place=[[Worcester, Massachusetts]] |year=1897 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JPQ7AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA34&lpg=PA34 |accessdate=September 7, 2007}}</ref> [[Samuel Spring]] was one of the first [[chaplain]]s of the [[American Revolution]].<ref name="Spring">{{cite web |title=Samuel Spring of Uxbridge, Revolutionary War Chaplain, by Michael Potaski |publisher=Blackstone Valley Tribune |url=http://www.blackstonevalleytribune.com/pdf/BLA.2008.12.05.pdf |format=PDF |accessdate=December 12, 2008 |page=5}}</ref> [[Deborah Sampson]] enlisted as "Robert Shurtlieff of Uxbridge".<ref name="NYT">{{cite news |work=New York Times |date=October 8, 1898 |title=DEBORAH SAMPSON.; How She Served as a Soldier in the Revolution − Her Sex Unknown to the Army.* |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1898/10/08/102078478.pdf |accessdate=October 31, 2007 |format=PDF}}</ref> [[Shays' Rebellion]] also began here, and Governor [[John Hancock]] quelled Uxbridge riots.<ref name="revolution">{{cite web |title=Quelling the opening salvos of Shay's rebellion |url=http://www.alexautographs.com/l-colrev.htm |publisher=alexautographs.com |accessdate=November 10, 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070812185125/http://www.alexautographs.com/l-colrev.htm <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate=August 12, 2007}}</ref><ref name="hancock">{{cite book |title=Supplement to the Acts and resolves of Massachusetts:Vo1.1, p. 148 |publisher=google books |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sjiAzbmkX14C&pg=PA148&lpg=PA148&dq=Sherrif+sent+to+Uxbridge,+by+John+Hancock,+1783&q= |accessdate=August 26, 2009 |year=1896}}</ref> [[Simeon Wheelock]] died protecting the [[Springfield Armory]].<ref name="walking">{{cite web |title=walking tours-Uxbridge |publisher=Blackstone Daily |url=http://www.blackstonedaily.com/Outdoors&Nature/WTuxbridge.htm |accessdate=September 23, 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928130800/http://www.blackstonedaily.com/Outdoors%26Nature/WTuxbridge.htm |archivedate=September 28, 2007 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Seth Reed was instrumental in adding "[[E pluribus unum]]" to [[Coins of the United States dollar|U.S. coins]].<ref name="e pluribus" /><ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite book |last=Buford |first=Mary Hunter |title=Seth Read, Lieut.-Col.Continental Army; Pioneer at Geneva, New York, 1787, and at Erie, Penn., June, 1795. His Ancestors and Descendants. |year=1895 |location=Boston, Mass. |pages=167 pages on CD in PDF Format.}}</ref><ref name="Origin">{{cite book |last=Preble |first=George Henry |title=Origin and History of the American Flag and of the Naval and Yacht Club Signals, Seals and Arms, and of the Principal National Songs of the United States; Volume II |publisher=Brown|location=Philadelphia |pages=695–696|year=1879}}</ref> [[George Washington|Washington]] slept here on his [[Inaugural]] tour.<ref name="halifax">{{cite web |title=Stanton River Tour |publisher=oldhalifax.com |url=http://www.oldhalifax.com/county/GeoWashington.htm |accessdate=May 1, 2008}}</ref><ref name="naviagator">{{cite web|title=Did George Washington Really Stay in Uxbridge |publisher=blackstone riever valley.com |url=http://www.blackstonerivervalley.com/navigator/towns/uxbridgearticle.php |accessdate=December 25, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081119155729/http://www.blackstonerivervalley.com/navigator/towns/uxbridgearticle.php |archivedate=November 19, 2008 }}</ref>
[[File:Jacob Aldrich House, National Historic Site, Uxbridge, MA.jpg|left|200x200px|thumb|Jacob Aldrich House; Quaker style house]] [[Religious Society of Friends|Quakers]] including [[Richard Mowry]] migrated here from [[Smithfield, Rhode Island]], and built mills, railroads, [[Jacob Aldrich House|houses]], tools and [[Conestoga wagon]] wheels.<ref name="walking" /><ref name="dhcd">{{cite web |title=Uxbridge, Worcester County |publisher=Department of Housing and Community Development |url=http://www.mass.gov/portal/gog_cache.jsp?q=cache:DYbVAWlgeqAJ:www.mass.gov/Ehed/docs/dhcd/profiles/304.doc+Uxbridge&access=p&output=xml_no_dtd&ie=UTF-8&client=mgov&site=EHEDx&proxystylesheet=mgov&oe=UTF-8 |accessdate=May 24, 2008}}</ref><ref name="cones">{{cite web |title=The Conestoga Wagon |publisher=The Conestoga Area Historical Society |url=http://www.rootsweb.com/~pacahs/wagon.htm |accessdate=September 23, 2007}}</ref> Southwick's store housed the Social and Instructive Library. [[Friends Meetinghouse (Uxbridge, Massachusetts)|Friends Meetinghouse]], next to [[Moses Farnum House|Moses Farnum]]'s farm, had prominent [[Abolitionism in the United States|abolitionists]] [[Abby Kelley Foster]] and [[Effingham Capron]] as members.<ref name="quaker2">{{cite web |title=Uxbridge, Friends Meetinghouse |publisher=NPS |url=http://www.nps.gov/archive/blac/the_corridor/map%20pages/sights%20map/millville.htm#friends |accessdate=September 29, 2007}}</ref><ref name="Archeology">{{cite web |publisher=University of Florida |year=1992 |title=The Historical Archeology of Mortuary Behavior: Coffin Hardware from Uxbridge, Massachusetts; Abstract: Edward Bell |url=http://www.clas.ufl.edu/users/davidson/Arch%20of%20Death/Week%2013/Bell%201990.pdf|format=PDF |accessdate=November 1, 2007}}</ref><ref name="Buffum">{{cite book |last=Buffum |first=Lucill |title=Elizabeth Buffme Chase- Her Life and Its Environment|publisher=Google books |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_IoEAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA264&lpg=PA264&dq=abby+kelley+uxbridge+ma+society+of+friends |year=1914}}</ref><ref name="meeting">{{cite web|title=The Uxbridge Meeting House |publisher=Blackstone Daily |url=http://www.blackstonedaily.com/quaker.htm |accessdate=September 23, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061101004755/http://www.blackstonedaily.com/quaker.htm |archivedate=November 1, 2006 }}</ref> [[Effingham Capron|Capron]] led the 450 member local anti-slavery society. Brister Pierce, formerly a slave in Uxbridge, was a signer of an 1835 petition to [[US House of Representatives|Congress]] demanding [[Abolitionism in the United States|abolition of slavery]] and the slave trade in the [[District of Columbia]].<ref>http://cummingtonhistoricalcommission.weebly.com/cummington-antislavery-movement-finding-aid.html | Cummington, MA historical commission.</ref>
=== Early transportation, education, public health and safety === [[Robert Taft Sr.|The Tafts]] built the [[Middle Post Road]]'s [[Blackstone River]] bridge in 1709.<ref name="Post Road">{{cite book |last=Holbrook |first=Stewart H |title=The Old Post Road: The Story of the Boston Post Road |publisher=McGraw Hill |year=1962 |location=New York}}</ref> "[[Teamsters]]" drove horse "team" freight wagons on the Worcester-Providence stage route. The [[Blackstone Canal]] brought horse-drawn barges to [[Providence, Rhode Island|Providence]] through Uxbridge for overnight stops.<ref name="hist" /><ref name="canal">{{cite web |title=History of the Canal, The Blackstone Canal: A Brief Overview of Its Historical Significance |publisher=Worcester Historical Museum |url=http://www.worcesterhistory.org/bcinfo/bcinfo-home.html |accessdate=September 23, 2007}}</ref><ref name="bridge">{{cite web |title=Stone Arch Bridge across Blackstone Canal in Blackstone River and Canal Heritage State Park. Uxbridge, Massachusetts, October 10, 2004 |publisher=Asgreev Photos |url=http://www.asergeev.com/pictures/archives/compress/2004/419/01.htm |accessdate=September 25, 2007}}</ref> The "crossroads village" was a junction on the [[Underground Railroad]].<ref name="Effingham" /> The [[Providence and Worcester Railroad|P&W Railroad]] ended canal traffic in 1848.
A 1732 vote "set up a school for ye town of Uxbridge".<ref name="hist" /> A grammar school was followed by 13 one-room district school houses, built for $2000 in 1797. [[Uxbridge Academy]] (1818) became a prestigious New England prep school.
Uxbridge voted against the smallpox [[variolation|vaccine]].<ref name="Washington" /> [[Samuel Willard (physician)|Samuel Willard]] treated smallpox victims,<ref name="elias">{{cite book |last=Backofen |first=Walter A |title=Elias Frost, M.D., and His Strategy for Being Remembered |year=2001 |page=6 |id=OCLC: 58438763}}</ref> was a forerunner of modern psychiatry, and ran the first hospital for mental illness in America.<ref name="worcester" /><ref name="cwmars1" /> Vital records recorded many infant deaths,<ref name="vitals" /> the smallpox death of Selectman [[Joseph Richardson House (Uxbridge, Massachusetts)|Joseph Richardson]], "Quincy", "dysentary", and tuberculosis deaths.<ref name="vitals" /><ref name="walking" /> [[Leonard White (physician)|Leonard White]] recorded a [[malaria]] outbreak here in 1896 that led to<ref name="malaria" /> firsts in the control of malaria as a mosquito-borne infection.<ref name="malaria">{{cite web |title=A History of Mosquitoes in Massachusetts, by Curtis R. Best |publisher=Northeast Mosquito Control Association |url=http://www.nmca.org/Nmca93-4.htm |accessdate=March 31, 2008}}</ref> Uxbridge led Massachusetts in robberies for a quarter of the year in 1922, and the town voted to hire its first nighttime police patrolman.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.uxbridge-ma.gov/Pages/UxbridgeMA_Police/police%20history | title=History of Policing in Uxbridge |accessdate=February 14, 2014}}</ref>
=== Industrial era: 19th century to late 20th century === Bog iron and three iron forges marked the colonial era, with the inception of large-scale industries beginning around 1775.<ref name="info" /> Examples of this development can be seen in the work of [[Richard Mowry]], who built and marketed equipment to manufacture woolen, linen, or cotton cloth,<ref name="NPS" /><ref name="national">{{cite web|title=Blackstone River Valley, New England's Historic National Park area; Navigator/Uxbridge|publisher=Blackstonerivervalley.com|url=http://www.blackstonerivervalley.com/navigator/towns/uxbridge.php|accessdate=December 6, 2007|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080104170917/http://www.blackstonerivervalley.com/navigator/towns/uxbridge.php|archivedate=January 4, 2008|df=mdy-all}}</ref> and [[gristmill]]s, [[sawmill]]s, distilleries, and large industries.<ref name="MHC" /> Uxbridge reached a peak of twenty different industrial [[mill (factory)|mills]].<ref name="MHC" /><ref name="walking" /> [[Daniel Day (Manufacturer)|Daniel Day]] built the first woolen mill in 1809.<ref name="hist" /><ref name="Washington" /> By 1855, 560 local workers made {{convert|2,500,000|yd|m}} of cloth ({{convert|14,204|mi|km}}).<ref name="info">[https://web.archive.org/web/20070927011002/http://www.mass.info/uxbridge.ma/description.htm] Massinfo-Uxbridge, Web Archive access date=December 2, 2017</ref><ref name="MHC" /> Uxbridge reached a peak of twenty different industrial [[mill (factory)|mills]].<ref name="MHC" /><ref name="walking" /> A small silver vein at Scadden, in southwest Uxbridge, led to unsuccessful commercial mining in the 1830s.<ref>[http://www.blissfulmeadows.com/sites/courses/layout9.asp?id=670&page=37415 Uxbridge Compendium article, 1866, Silver Mine, Blissful Meadows]</ref>
[[File:2 Capron Street, Uxbridge.JPG|thumb|250x250|right|Charles Capron House, 2 Capron Street. The Capron family was prominent in the Industrial era at Uxbridge Center where Capron Mill is located.]] Innovations included [[power loom]]s, vertical integration of wool to clothing, [[cashmere wool]]-synthetic blends, "wash and wear", yarn spinning techniques, and latch hook kits. Villages included mills, shops, worker housing, and farms. Wm. Arnold's [[Ironstone, Massachusetts|Ironstone]] cotton mill, later made Kentucky Blue Jeans,<ref name="walking" /> and Seth Read's gristmill, later housed [[Bay State Arms]]. Hecla and [[Wheelockville]] housed [[American Woolen Company|American Woolen]], [[Waucantuck Mill Complex|Waucantuck Mill]], [[Lowell family|Hilena Lowell]]'s shoe factory, and [[Draper Corporation]]. [[Daniel Day (manufacturer)|Daniel Day]], [[Jerry Wheelock]], and [[Luke Taft]] used water-powered mills. [[Moses Taft]]'s ([[Stanley Woolen Mill|Central Woolen]]) operated continuously making [[American Civil War|Civil War]] cloth.<ref name="walking" /><ref name="stanley">{{cite web |title=Stanely Woolen Mill, The Story |publisher=Deaneredevelopment.com |url=http://deaneredevelopment.com/stanley-woolen-mill-story.html |accessdate=January 13, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110709004119/http://deaneredevelopment.com/stanley-woolen-mill-story.html |archivedate=July 9, 2011 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
[[North Uxbridge]] housed Clapp's 1810 cotton mill, Chandler Taft's and [[Richard Sayles House|Richard Sayles]]' [[Rivulet Mill Complex|Rivulet Mill]], the granite quarry, and [[Robert Rogerson|Rogerson's village]]. [[Rogerson's Village Historic District|Crown and Eagle Mill]] was "a masterpiece of early industrial architecture".<ref name="Crown">{{cite book|last=Langenbach |first=Randolph |title=The Crown and Eagle Mills, A remarkable Massachusetts Relic of the Industrial Revolution now in danger of destruction |work=Boston Globe Sunday Magazine |location=Boston |date=August 15, 1971}}</ref> Blanchard's granite quarry provided curb stones to [[New York City]] and regional public works projects.<ref name="MHC">{{cite web |title=MHC Reconnaissance Survey Town Report: Uxbridge; Report Date: 1984 Associated Regional Report: Central Massachusetts; |publisher=Massachusetts Historical Commission; |year=1984 |url=https://www.sec.state.ma.us/mhc/mhcpdf/townreports/Cent-Mass/uxb.pdf |format=PDF |deadurl=no |accessdate=August 23, 2016 |archiveurl=https://archive.today/20160823161759/https://www.sec.state.ma.us/mhc/mhcpdf/townreports/Cent-Mass/uxb.pdf |archivedate=August 23, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref name="walking" /><ref name="Blanchard">{{cite book |last=Crane |first=Ellery Bicknell |title=Historic Homes and Institutions and Genealogical and Personal Memories of Worcester County, Massachusetts with a history of Worcester Society of Antiquity; |publisher=Lewis |year=1907 |location=Chicago and New York |page=385 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rqvWQWtFKl0C&pg=RA1-PA7&lpg=RA1-PA7&dq=historic+homes+and+institutions+and+geneological+and+personal+memoirs+vol+iii+elery+bicknell+crane&source=web&ots=zL5ELNGMnH&sig=nMx43ON2yNp1VCT4PoOMcp85-Uw#PRA5-PA385,M1}}</ref> [[Peter Rawson Taft]]'s grandson, [[William Howard Taft]], visited [[Samuel Taft House]].<ref name="visits">{{cite news |title=Taft Visits Home of His Ancestors |work=New York Times |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1910/08/20/105086742.pdf |accessdate=November 27, 2007 |format=PDF |date=August 20, 1910}}</ref>
[[John Capron|John Sr.]], [[Effingham Capron|Effingham]] and [[John Capron|John W. Capron]]'s mill pioneered US [[satinets]] and woolen power looms.<ref name="MHC" /><ref name="hist" /><ref name="info" /><ref name="water">{{cite web |title=Blackstone River Watershed |publisher=Executive Office of Environmental Affairs, Mass. Gov. |url=http://www.mass.gov/envir/water/blackstone/blackstone.htm |accessdate=September 23, 2007}}</ref> Charles A. Root, Edward Bachman, and [[Harold Walter]] expanded [[Bachman Uxbridge Worsted Company|Bachman-Uxbridge]], and exhibited leadership in women's fashion.<ref>{{cite news |title=TEXTILES: The Pride of Uxbridge|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,818770,00.html |accessdate=July 2, 2012 |newspaper=Time Magazine U.S|date=August 24, 1953|author=Unknown |agency=Time Inc}}</ref> The company manufactured [[United States Army|US Army]] uniforms for the [[American Civil War|Civil War]], [[World War I]], [[World War II]], the [[Army Medical Department (United States)|nurse corps]], and the first [[U.S. Air Force|Air Force]] dress uniforms, dubbed "Uxbridge Blue".<ref name="walking" /><ref>{{cite web |title=Of Uniform Concern: A Casual History of the USAF 'Blue Suit' |url=http://www.authorsden.com/categories/article_top.asp?catid=73&id=52282|work=AuthorsDen|publisher=AuthorsDen, Inc |accessdate=July 2, 2012 |author=Kalikiano Kalei |year=2009}}</ref> ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine covered Uxbridge Worsted's proposed a buyout to be the top US woolen company.<ref>[http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,819703,00.html]"Time Clock-American Woolen will ask stockholders to approve buy-out by Bachman-Uxbrige", ''Time Magazine, March 29, 1954''</ref> The largest plant of one of the largest US yarn companies, [[Bernat Mill|Bernat Yarn]], was located here from the 1960s to the 1980s. A historic company called Information Services operated from Uxbridge, and managed subscription services for ''[[The New Republic]]'', among other publications, in the later 20th century.
=== Late 20th century to present === [[File:RiverBendFarm 091.jpg|thumb|190px|left|[[Blackstone River and Canal Heritage State Park]]]] State and national parks developed around mills and rivers were restored.<ref name="cleaning">{{cite web |title=Cleaning up the Blackstone |publisher=National Park Service|url=http://www.nps.gov/blac/naturescience/restoring-the-river.htm |accessdate=November 16, 2007}}</ref> ''[[The Great Gatsby (1974 film)|The Great Gatsby]]'' (1974) and ''[[Oliver's Story]]'' (1978) were filmed locally including at [[Stanley Woolen Mill]]. The [[Blackstone River Valley National Heritage Corridor|Blackstone Valley National Historic Park]]<ref name="nps">{{cite web |title=John H. Chaffee Blackstone Valley National Heritage Corridor; Massachusetts/Rhode Island; Birthplace of the Industrial Revolution|publisher=National Park Service; US Department of the Interior |url=http://www.nps.gov/blac/ |accessdate=September 23, 2007}}</ref> contains the {{convert|1000|acre|km2|adj=on}}[[Blackstone River and Canal Heritage State Park|Blackstone Canal Heritage State == Government == {{Worcester County politicians || county = Worcester | align = right | wraparound = yes | state_rep = [[Kevin Kuros|Kevin J. Kuros]] (R)) | state_sen = Ryan Fattman (R) | gov_councilors = Jen Caissie (R) | fed_rep = [[Jim McGovern (congressman)|James P. McGovern]] (D-[[United States House of Representatives, Massachusetts District 2|2nd Dist.]]) | fed_sen = [[Scott Brown]] (R)<br />[[John Kerry]] (D) }} Uxbridge has a [[Board of Selectmen]] and [[town meeting]] government, with officials listed in the top infobox:<ref>[http://www.uxbridge-ma.gov/HTML/Selectmen.shtml Uxbridge Massachusetts Website – Board of Selectmen (1.00.00)<!-- Bot generated title -->].</ref>
Local government granted the [[Lydia Taft|first woman]] in America the [[right to vote]],<ref name="Washington">{{cite book |last=Chapin |first=Judge Henry |title=Address Delivered at the Unitarian Church in Uxbridge, 1864 |page=172 |publisher=Charles Hamilton Press (Harvard Library; from Google Books) |year=1881 |location=Worcester, MA |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ua-pgcKRY2QC&pg=RA1-PA172&lpg=RA1-PA172&q=address+delivered+at+unitarian+church+}}</ref> nixed a smallpox vaccine in 1775,<ref name="Washington" /> and defied the Massachusetts [[Massachusetts Secretary of the Commonwealth|Secretary of State]] by approving women jurors.<ref name="juries">{{cite news |title=Selectman affirm right of Women to Serve on Juries |work=New York Times |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1922/07/02/107064791.pdf |format=PDF |date=July 2, 1922}}</ref> The 2009 Board of Health made Uxbridge the third community in the US to ban tobacco sales in pharmacies, but later reversed this.<ref>[http://www.tobaccofreerx.org/#!copy-of-local-efforts/cheh| TobaccoFreeRx.org | Local Efforts]</ref>
State agencies control county elected offices (see info box). In fact, Uxbridge has a District Courthouse.
== Geography == <!-- commented out link to photo --- (For a beautiful photo gallery of local geography see this link) [http://www.asergeev.com/php/searchph/links.php?keywords=uxbridge]---> The town is {{convert|30.4|sqmi}}, of which {{convert|0.8|sqmi}}, or 2.73%, is water. It is situated {{convert|39.77|mi}} southwest of [[Boston]], {{convert|16|mi}} southeast of [[Worcester, Massachusetts|Worcester]], and {{convert|20|mi}} northwest of [[Providence, Rhode Island|Providence]]. Elevations range from {{convert|200|ft|m}} to {{convert|577|ft|m}} above sea level. It borders [[Douglas, Massachusetts|Douglas]], [[Mendon, Massachusetts|Mendon]], [[Millville, Massachusetts|Millville]], [[Northbridge, Massachusetts|Northbridge]], and [[Sutton, Massachusetts]], plus the [[Rhode Island]] towns of [[Burrillville, Rhode Island|Burrillville]] and [[North Smithfield, Rhode Island|North Smithfield]].

== Demographics == {{Historical populations | type=USA | 1850|2457 | 1860|3133 | 1870|3058 | 1880|3111 | 1890|3408 | 1900|3599 | 1910|4671 | 1920|5384 | 1930|6285 | 1940|6417 | 1950|7007 | 1960|7789 | 1970|8253 | 1980|8374 | 1990|10415 | 2000|11156 | 2010|13457 | 2015|13892 | footnote=* = population estimate. {{Historical populations/Massachusetts municipalities references}} }} The [[2010 United States Census]]<ref name="GR2">{{cite web |url=http://factfinder2.census.gov|publisher=[[United States Census Bureau]]|accessdate=January 31, 2008 |title=American FactFinder}}</ref> population was 13,457, representing a growth rate of 20.6%, with 5,056 households, a density rate of 166.31 units per square mile. 95.7% were [[White (U.S. Census)|White]], 1.7% [[Asian (U.S. Census)|Asian]], 0.90% [[Hispanic (U.S. Census)|Hispanic]], 0.3% [[African American (U.S. Census)|African American]], and 1.4% other. [[Population density]] was 442.66 people/ mile<sup>2</sup> (170.77/km²). [[Per capita income]] was $24,540, and 4.7% fell below the [[poverty line]]. There were 9,959 registered voters in 2010.
== Economy == High tech, services, distribution, life sciences, hospitality, local government, education and tourism offer local jobs. A 618,000 square feet (57,400 m2) distribution center serves [[Fortune 500]] [[BJ's Wholesale Club]]'s, northern division. The July 2013 unemployment was 6.9%.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20040301152122/http://www.city-data.com/city/Uxbridge-Massachusetts.html ] City-Data.com/City/Uxbridge-Nassachusetts</ref>
== Education == Local schools include Taft Pre-K-2, Whitin Elementary, McCloskey Middle School, [[Uxbridge High School (Massachusetts)|Uxbridge High]] (built in 2012) and Our Lady of the Valley Regional. [[Blackstone Valley Regional Vocational Technical High School|Valley Tech]] ([[Upton, Massachusetts|Upton]]) houses [[Quinsigamond Community College]]. The ''[[New York Times]]'' called Uxbridge education reforms a "little revolution" to meet family needs.<ref name="times">{{cite news |title=The ramparts of a little revolution in education |work=New York Times |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9F02E0DA1039F930A25752C0A960958260&sec=&spon=&pagewanted=1 |accessdate=April 4, 2008 |first=Tamar |last=Lewin |date=January 13, 1996}}</ref>
== Healthcare == <!-- Image with inadequate rationale removed: [[File:UMMS Logo.png|UMMS Logo|thumb|left|180px| UMASS Medical Center affiliate, Tri River health center, Uxbridge]] --> [[Community health centers in the United States|Tri-River Family Health Center]] ([[University of Massachusetts Medical School|UMass Medical]]) offers primary care. [[Milford Regional Medical Center|Milford Regional]], [[Landmark Medical Center|Landmark M/C]], hospices and long term care are nearby, or local.
== Transportation == === Rail === The nearest [[MBTA Commuter Rail]] stops are [[Forge Park/495 (MBTA station)|Forge Park/495]] on the [[Franklin Line]] and [[Grafton (MBTA station)|Grafton]] and [[Worcester (Amtrak station)|Worcester]] on the [[Framingham/Worcester Line]], 15 miles away. The [[Northeast Corridor]] [[Providence (Amtrak station)|Providence Amtrak station]] has trains with top speeds of 150 MPH. The [[Providence and Worcester Railroad]] freight line passes two former local stations.
=== Highways === [[File:MA Route 146.svg|20px]] [[Massachusetts Route 146|Route 146]]<ref>http://www.gribblenation.net/nepics/ma/146/ma146a-on146s.jpg</ref> links [[Worcester, Massachusetts|Worcester]], [[File:I-290.svg|20px]] [[Interstate 290 (Massachusetts)|I-290]], and [[File:I-90.svg|20px]] [[Interstate 90 (Massachusetts)|I-90]] to [[Providence, Rhode Island|Providence]] at [[File:I-95.svg|20px]] [[Interstate 95 (Rhode Island)|I-95]] and [[File:I-295.svg|20px]] [[Interstate 295 (Rhode Island)|I-295]]. [[File:MA Route 16.svg|20px]] [[Massachusetts Route 16|Route 16]] links to [[Connecticut]] via [[File:I-395.svg|20px]] [[Interstate 395 (Connecticut-Massachusetts)|I-395]], and [[Boston]], by [[File:I-495.svg|20px]] [[Interstate 495 (Massachusetts)|I-495]]. [[File:MA Route 122.svg|25px]] [[Massachusetts Route 122|Route 122]] connects [[Northbridge, Massachusetts|Northbridge]] and [[Woonsocket]]. [[File:MA Route 146A.svg|20px]] [[Massachusetts Route 146A|Route 146A]] goes into [[North Smithfield]]. [[File:MA Route 98.svg|20px]] [[Massachusetts Route 98|Route 98]] leads to [[Burrillville]].
=== Airports === [[T. F. Green Airport|TF Green State Airport Warwick]]-[[Providence, RI]], [[Worcester Regional Airport|Worcester airport]], and [[Logan International Airport|Boston Logan International Airport]] have commercial flights. [[Hopedale Industrial Park Airport|Hopedale Airport]], {{convert|7.2|mi}} away, and [[Worcester Regional Airport|Worcester airport]] have general aviation. <!-- [http://www.airplanemanager.com/Airports/MA75|Sky Glen Airport] in Uxbridge, is listed as MA75, for airport codes and current landing capability or activity is unknown, though the [[FAA]] website lists it as "active" 04/10.(VFR only). --> A private air strip, Sky Glen Airport on Quaker Highway, is still listed on FAA sites, though the map location shows it within a dense industrial park, and at its peak of operations, it saw very low traffic.<ref>[http://www.airplanemanager.com/Airports/MA75 Sky Glen Airport]</ref>

[[Daniel Day (manufacturer)|Daniel Day]] started the first woolen mill in the Blackstone Valley later also known as "Scott's Mill", the current factory recently housed Berrocoo Inc., extending a 200-year family enterprise, now a prominent yarn company.. File:Rivulet Mill Complex, 1814, North Uxbridge, MA.JPG|[[Rivulet Mill Complex]], 1814, [[North Uxbridge]], The original mill was built by Chandler Taft, and later owned by [[Richard Sayles House|Richard Sayles]]. File:Richard Sayles House, Uxbridge, MA.jpg|[[Richard Sayles House]] is a historic home built by Richard Sayles who owned the Rivulet Mill. Located at 80 Mendon Street. File:JohnandEffinghamCapronMill 195.jpg|The [[Capron Mill]], 1820, built by [[John Capron]] Sr. and his sons Effingham, and John, circa 1820 manufactured the first [[satinets]], used the first [[power loom]]s for woolens in America, and made US military uniforms for over 140 years, including the first US Air Force dress uniform, "Uxbridge 1683", aka Uxbridge Blue. File:2 Capron Street, Uxbridge.JPG|Charles Capron House, 2 Capron Street. The Capron family was prominent in the industrial era. File:Crown&EagleMillUxbridge 101.jpg|Crown & Eagle Mill, built in 1824 by [[Robert Rogerson]], a son of British immigrants, and a musician, it is considered a masterpiece of early American Industrial architecture, today the heart of [[Rogerson's Village Historic District]]. File:Larkin Building, Uxbridge, MA.png|The Company Store at Rogerson's Village, now known as the Larkin Building File:Rogersons Village Housing, Uxbridge, MA.jpg| Rogersons Village mill worker housing, Rhode Island System of mill villages File:JRichardson House, Uxbridge, MA.jpg|[[Joseph Richardson House (Uxbridge, Massachusetts)|Joseph Richardson House]], on the national historic register, Joseph Richardson was a Selectman, and landowner in South Uxbridge, who died of smallpox in 1825. File:Stanley Woolen Mill Uxbridge MA reflected in Blackstone canal.jpg|[[Stanley Woolen Mill]], 1852, built by [[Moses Taft]], with view of the Blackstone Canal, was the scene for two movies, The Great Gatsby, 1974, and Oliver's Story, 1978. In 1989, it had been the longest continuously operating family-owned mill in the US. This mill ran 24/7 making Civil War blue woolen cloth for military uniforms. File:Canal-uxbridgeMA.jpg|Canoes on the [[Blackstone Canal]]. The Blackstone Canal was built starting in 1824 and provided early freight transport by horse pulled barges from Uxbridge and Worcester, to the port of Providence and returns. Uxbridge was the overnight stopping point, and had close mercantile ties to Providence. File:Stone Arch Bridge on Hartford Ave, Uxbridge MA.jpg|The [[Taft family|Taft]] brothers built the first bridge across the [[Blackstone River]] in 1709. This stone arch bridge is a familiar scene walking northward at the Blackstone Canal Heritage State Park. File:River Bend Farm, Blackstone River and Canal Heritage State Park RBFVC.jpg|River Bend Farm Interpretive Center at Blacktone River and Canal Heritage State Park File:Ezra Taft Benson (1811).jpg|[[Ezra T. Benson|Ezra Taft Benson]] (1811–1869) ran a hotel in Uxbridge, married two sisters from Northbridge, [[LDS Church|LDS]] [[Quorum of the Twelve Apostles (LDS Church)|Apostle]], Missionary to the Hawaiian Islands, and Utah Territorial Legislator File:Arthur macarthur sr.gif|[[Arthur MacArthur Sr.]], born to Scottish nobility, grew up in Uxbridge, circa 1828, became [[Wisconsin]]'s 4th [[Governor]] for a brief period, and its [[Lt. Governor]], and served as Chief Justice, of the US DC District Court. He was the Grandfather of General [[Douglas MacArthur]] File:Unitarian Church-Uxbridge.jpg|Unitarian Church at Uxbridge where Judge [[Henry Chapin]], three term Worcester Mayor, delivered a famous 1864 published historical address. Judge Chapin was as a prominent [[American Unitarian Association|Unitarian Church]] leader in [[Massachusetts]]. This church was prominent in the Industrial period of this community. File:Honorable Henry Chapin, Three term mayor of Worcester, Massachusetts.jpg|Judge [[Henry Chapin]], 2nd Mayor of Worcester, 1849–1851), three term Mayor, Chief Judge, and Practicing Attorney who lived in Uxbridge, and delivered a famous historical address to the Uxbridge Unitarian Church in 1864 recording the account of America's First Woman Voter, [[Lydia Taft]] File:Effingham Capron Park, Uxbridge, MA.jpg|[[Effingham Capron]] (1791–1859) was a national, state and local anti-slavery champion. He and his brother John Capron Jr. and their father, ran the [[Capron Mill]] at Uxbridge. The historic park commemorates the contributions of [[Effingham Capron]] here and to the USA. File:Franklin Bartlett.jpg|[[Franklin Bartlett]] was a US Congressman from New York from 1893–1897. He fought in the Spanish–American War and his brother [[Willard Bartlett]] was Chief Justice of the [[New York Court of Appeals]]. File:Wheelockak.jpg|[[Arthur K. Wheelock Jr.]], [[National Gallery of Art|National Gallery Curator]] Northern Baroque Art, grew up in Uxbridge family which had started and operated multiple mils for 200 years. A descendent of Rev. Ralph Wheelock who pioneered public education in America. <!-- Deleted image removed: File:Oppewall.jpg|[[Jeannine Oppewall]], Hollywood film art producer, born in 1946, and raised in Uxbridge, four time academy award nominee, with multiple films including Seabiscuit and Bridges of Madison County. --> File:Brian Skerry.JPG|[[Brian Skerry]], At Boston University, 2011, born 1962, Underwater Photographer, With National Geographic, Sounding the Alarm for Global Sealife. File:UxbridgeHigh, MA.png|[[Uxbridge High School (Massachusetts)|Uxbridge High School]], Quaker Highway, S. Uxbridge, MA, built 2012. File:Uxbridge Free Public Library.jpg|[[Uxbridge Free Public Library]]. The Thayer Family donated the local public library which is located in the Uxbridge Common Historic District. File:C.R. Thomson House and Barn.jpg|[[C.R. Thomson House and Barn]], today a golf course with banquet facilities, located at Chockalog Rd. in SW Uxbridge. File:Granite Store - Uxbridge, Massachusetts - DSC02858.JPG|Once a department store in the mid 1800s, [[Granite Store (Uxbridge, Massachusetts)|The Granite Store]] is located on Hecla Street in Uxbridge. File:Uxbiridge, MA looking south on Route 122, October 26, 2012.jpg|Fall Scene Downtown Uxbridge, October 2012 looking south on MA route 122 before Hurricane Sandy and when an historic old bank building was still standing in the left background down the street. </gallery>
